title: Most underrated type designers?
content:
There are a lot of great type designers out there. Some are getting the attention they deserve, while others still seem to be living the life of the "undiscovered talent."

I've come across a few recently who I hadn't heard about and I figured this could be a good way for others who scan the pages of Typophile to learn about designers they wouldn't otherwise know about. Who do you think is underrated?
author: TBiddy

comments.content: No fair, Terry. You start. ;^)

Apparently, Paul Barnes.

hhp

Good one, Hrant. I guess we should define "underrated" here. Are you looking for type designers unknown to graphic designers, unknown to other type designers, or unknown to Typophiles? Those are three levels of increasing knowledge.

Here are those that first come to my mind:  
 [Hubert Jocham](http://web.archive.org/web/20110417123439/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Hubert%20Jocham), [Laura Meseguer](http://web.archive.org/web/20110417123439/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Laura%20Meseguer), [Xavier Dupré](http://web.archive.org/web/20110417123439/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Xavier%20Dupre), [Alan Greene](http://web.archive.org/web/20110417123439/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Alan%20Greene).
Well, with this bunch there probably aren't many unknown to type designers. Why don't we go with unknown to graphic designers. Though I think everyone could potentially learn something new. :)

Probably most graphic designers, who are not also type whackos like us, don't know who designed many of the faces they use. My guess is that they just know the big names. That leads me to say that underrated may not be the term. It may be "under-the-radar" instead :-)

ChrisL

I would actually shoot for under-rated by us. That would teach us the most.

Then we can tell the graphic designers about them, and the under-rateds could leapfrog, which might make up for their low-key past. And if they don't like that, tough - they shouldn't do such great work. :-)

Interesting topic. When I think of it I wonder why it hasn't appeared earlier? Anyway, how do graphic designers or design oriented people define whether a type designer is underrated or not? By their appearance in articles etc or by having their typefaces used in work. It would be fun to have some questions like this in a survey done by some design magazine. I myself find it hard to pinpoint the word underrated... but I'm leaning toward the case where someone who makes quality products and is fairly known, but seldom used by graphic designers. On the other hand some type designers are having less time to make commercial faces because they work more with custom type.
Also varies with location - MFBenton is apparently more underrated in Europe than he is in the US.

For example: I think [Dino dos Santos](http://web.archive.org/web/20110417123439/http:/www.dstype.com/) has done some amazing work. But only recently have I discovered it.

Though they might disagree...I think they are pretty well known amongst designers and type designers alike.

_a penny for every Nokia phone sold?_

There is a difference between a bundled font and an OEM font.

_does anyone do royalties on custom font work?_

It's not about royalties, but about fair value.  
One of the financial considerations made by corporations (and governments) that commission custom fonts is to compare the cost of licensing a retail font for their multiple workstations, with the cost of commissioning a proprietary design.

_it’s kind of like me dreaming of winning the lottery when I never buy a ticket._

Sure, contracted talent doesn't get OEM "points" in this business, but that is the result of corporate concentration, nothing to do with gambling. One can still imagine how things might be without the virtual monopoly exercised by a handful of computer companies.

Nonsense, it's just a different perspective.  
The MRSP I was referring to is retail font price, not the cost of Vista. The idea that people actually buy font licences may seem somewhat bizarre at MS, but indulge me please, it's the reality for most type designers.  
Say an OpenType font family of four styles retails for $100.  
When an independent foundry sells a licence for that, the type designer makes $30 - $90, depending on whether the sale is "foundry direct" or through a distributor.  
However, when the same designer's OT family is bundled with Vista, the designer will end up making what, a couple of cents per installed family?  
Munch et al are great philanthropists :-)

Nick, we've read your rants about 'bundling' many times before. But to somehow claim that any type designer who does work-for-hire work that is bundled is some kind of traitor is taking things too far.

The leap that the designers who worked on the ClearType Collection fonts are "underrated" is also bizare. You picked the wrong thread to hang your crusade on - Matthew Carter, Luc(as), Jeremy Tankard, John Hudson etc., could hardly be described as underrated before working on this project and if anything being involved adds to their exposure.

Cheers, Si
